It did mediate forgiveness and hope, especially through the sacrifices. The law was a system of “types and shadows,” that is, of significant elements foreshadowing Christ and inviting trust in God through Him.

I will be their God, and they . . . my people. This declaration is the summary of God’s blessings promised in His covenant (Lev. 26:12; cf. 7:23).

title: Jer 31:34
text:
31:34 Know the Lord. See “True Knowledge of God” at 9:24.

For I will forgive. The basis of the promises in vv. 32, 33 will be a new work of redemption that secures the forgiveness of sins (see Heb. 10:1–17).

remember their sin no more. The continuing cycle of sacrifices under the old covenant provided a constant reminder of sins (Heb. 10:3, 4, 11). The words “no more” underscore that the satisfaction made for sins in the redemption to come will be perfect, making any further sacrifices unnecessary.

title: Jer 31:35–36
text: 31:35, 36 gives the sun . . . moon and the stars. The enduring order of the heavenly bodies is made the measure of God’s commitment to His people (33:20, 21, 25, 26).

title: Jer 31:38
text:
31:38 the city. Jerusalem.

Tower of Hananel . . . Corner Gate. Opposite ends of the city, signifying its entirety (see 2 Chr. 26:9; Zech. 14:10, 11). The restoration of Jerusalem will be the first sign of the fulfillment of the new covenant promise.

title: Jer 31:39
text: 31:39 Gareb . . . Goah. Unidentified locations in Jerusalem.

title: Jer 31:40
text: 31:40 valley. That is, the Valley of the Son of Hinnom (7:31 note).

title: Jer 32:1
text: 32:1 tenth year of Zedekiah. That is, 587 b.c. This chapter recounts the first of several exchanges between Jeremiah and Zedekiah in this period. See 21:3–7; 34:1–7; 37:3–8, 17–20; 38:14–28.

title: Jer 32:7
text:
32:7 Anathoth. This village was Jeremiah’s hometown; see 1:1.

right of redemption by purchase is yours. Hanamel may be selling because of debt, and asking Jeremiah to be the “close relative” who redeems (31:11 note). By normal standards, it is absurd to buy a field when the whole land is about to be lost.

title: Jer 32:9
text: 32:9 seventeen shekels of silver. This amount is probably a normal price, though under the circumstances the field was worthless.

title: Jer 32:15
text: 32:15 Houses and fields and vineyards . . . in this land. The significance of the purchase is that Judah will again possess its historic land and enjoy normal life in it. It therefore symbolizes that aspect of the new covenant promise (29:14 and note; 31:38–40).

title: Jer 32:20
text:
32:20 signs and wonders. See Ex. 7:3.

and among all mankind. This confession stresses God’s rule over the whole world.

title: Jer 32:21
text: 32:21 This description is repeated from Deut. 26:8. See also v. 20; Ex. 15:14–16.

title: Jer 32:29
text: 32:29 offerings have been made to Baal. Typical elements in Jeremiah’s accusation against Judah (1:16; 7:18; 19:13; cf. Deut. 31:29).

title: Jer 32:33
text: 32:33 have not listened. See 2:30; 5:3; 7:24; 11:8.

title: Jer 32:35
text: 32:35 Molech. “Molech” is probably the title of a god (rather than a proper name) who was worshiped by the Phoenicians, Moabites, Ammonites, and others in a ritual involving child sacrifice (Lev. 18:21; 20:2–5; 2 Kin. 23:10).

title: Jer 32:37
text: 32:37 Jeremiah reaffirms Moses’ promise of restoration from exile (Deut. 30:3–5). The suddenness and improbability of this promise, following the tirade of vv. 26–35, is explained by the rhetorical question “Is anything too hard for me?” (v. 27; cf. v. 17).

title: Jer 32:40
text: 32:40 everlasting covenant. See 31:31–36 and notes.

title: Jer 32:44
text: 32:44 Benjamin . . . Negeb. These regions represent the territorial extent of Judah at the time of the Exile (17:26; 33:13).

title: Jer 33:2
text: 33:2 who made the earth. See note 10:12. God’s creation is here the ground of His power both to judge and to save (32:17).

title: Jer 33:3
text: 33:3 great and hidden things. A similar phrase in Is. 48:6 also speaks of salvation as new creation. See Dan. 2:47.

title: Jer 33:6
text: 33:6 Behold. The change in the Lord’s purpose is not motivated by any change in Judah, but by His decision. See 30:8, 16; 32:36, for similar transitions.

title: Jer 33:11
text: 33:11 mirth . . . gladness . . . bridegroom . . . bride. Contrast 7:34; 16:9. These circumstances will be brought about by the new covenant.

title: Jer 33:17
text: 33:17 This promise is not finally to restore the monarchy, but to inaugurate the messianic kingdom (23:5; 30:9; 2 Sam. 7:12–16; cf. 1 Kin. 2:4).

title: Jer 33:18
text: 33:18 the Levitical priests. The priest’s role was essential to the administration of the covenant (Ex. 28; 29; Deut. 10:8; 18:1). They also had a covenant of their own with the Lord (Num. 25:12, 13; 1 Sam. 2:30, 35). The promise of a perpetual priestly ministry is fulfilled by Christ Himself (Heb. 5:6–10; 7:11–25).

title: Jer 33:20–21
text: 33:20, 21 covenant with the day and . . . night. The permanence of the institutions now envisaged is in stark contrast with 7:1–15. Such permanence is only comprehensible in the framework of the new covenant—though the need for faithfulness is never set aside (32:40 and note).

title: Jer 33:22
text: 33:22 cannot be numbered . . . sands of the sea. In these promises concerning the messianic kingdom, the promises to Abraham are also fulfilled (Gen. 22:17; contrast 15:8).

title: Jer 33:24
text: 33:24 two clans. The reference to these “clans” is ambiguous. It could refer to the kingdoms of Israel and Judah (v. 14) or to the royal family of David and the priestly family of Levi (vv. 17, 18).

title: Jer 33:26
text: 33:26 Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob. The new covenant is a fulfillment of the covenant with Abraham that embraced all peoples (Gen. 12:3). See note on v. 22.

title: Jer 34–36
text: 34:1–36:32 These chapters narrate scenes of rejection of the word of the Lord that led to final judgment on Judah. King Zedekiah is condemned for going back on his promise to free slaves (ch. 34), and the people of Judah are reproved for failing to learn a lesson from the example of the faithful Rechabites (ch. 35). King Jehoiakim rejects Jeremiah’s message and burns the prophet’s scroll (ch. 36).

title: Jer 34:1
text: 34:1 all the kingdoms . . . fighting against Jerusalem. It was required that vassal nations join in battle with their overlord.

title: Jer 34:4–5
text: 34:4, 5 not die by the sword . . . die in peace. Zedekiah’s precise fate was left obscure in 21:4–7; 32:3–5; but see 52:11. The point here is that he will not die in battle.

title: Jer 34:7
text: 34:7 Lachish and Azekah. These were fortified cities of Judah (2 Chr. 11:5, 9). The verse gives a glimpse of the last days of Judah. Jerusalem knew the enemy was closing in as the outlying cities fell one by one. A pottery fragment dating from 588 b.c. carried this message to the commander at Lachish: “we are watching for the signals of Lachish . . . we cannot see Azekah.”

title: Jer 34:8
text: 34:8 proclamation of liberty to them. According to Ex. 21:2–11; Lev. 25:39–55; Deut. 15:12–18, slaves were to be released in the last year of a seven-year cycle. Zedekiah’s “covenant” (or solemn undertaking) reflects his ambivalence between listening to Jeremiah and his own political advisers.

title: Jer 34:15–16
text:
34:15, 16 repented . . . turned around. These two verbs effectively portray Judah’s fickleness (3:6, 14 notes).

profaned my name. The blatant disregard for the law regarding the release of slaves is a repudiation of the Lord Himself (note the analogy between the “covenants” of vv. 8, 13).

title: Jer 34:18
text: 34:18 the calf that they cut . . . between its parts. See Gen. 15:18 and note. This sort of action accompanied making a covenant. It illustrated the penalty that would fall on a person who broke the covenant.

title: Jer 35:2
text:
35:2 house of the Rechabites. Most of what is known of this clan is in this chapter.

house of the Lord . . . chambers. These rooms were used for storage (1 Kin. 6:5; Neh. 13:4, 5).

title: Jer 35:3
text: 35:3 Jeremiah. One of two persons other than the prophet himself named “Jeremiah,” mentioned in the book (see 52:1).

title: Jer 35:4
text: 35:4 man of God. Another name for a prophet (1 Kin. 12:22).

title: Jer 35:6–7
text: 35:6, 7 The vow taken by Jonadab the son of Rechab commits his descendants to a nomadic life, with impermanent lodging and abstaining from wine. This life was a voluntary commitment not required by the Mosaic law (Deut. 6:10, 11; 7:13).

title: Jer 35:19
text: 35:19 shall never lack a man to stand before me. See 33:17, 18. Such a promise might be expected for a king, and even for priests, but not for the obscure Rechabites. It is used here to contrast ominously with what Jehoiakim and the Davidic dynasty can expect.

title: Jer 36:1
text: 36:1 fourth year of Jehoiakim. That is, 605 b.c., the year of Nebuchadnezzar’s first move against Jerusalem (25:1 note).

title: Jer 36:2
text: 36:2 Take a scroll and write on it. The present account is an important guide to understanding how prophetic books were written. Jeremiah’s oracles were spoken over a long period (25:3), and are here gathered into a collection (Is. 8:16 and note).

title: Jer 36:4
text: 36:4 Baruch. This is the second mention of Jeremiah’s scribe (32:12). His activity suggests that he had a role in compiling the Book of Jeremiah.

title: Jer 36:5
text: 36:5 I am banned. This statement probably means he was banned from the temple area because of his unpopularity with the authorities (26:2–11).

title: Jer 36:9
text: 36:9 In the fifth year . . . the ninth month. That is, December, 604 b.c.

title: Jer 36:21
text: 36:21 Jehudi. Baruch is no longer the reader, presumably being in hiding (v. 19). The absence of Jeremiah and Baruch focuses Jehoiakim’s response on the words themselves.

title: Jer 36:23
text: 36:23 the entire scroll was consumed in the fire. The contrast with Josiah could not be stronger (2 Kin. 22:11–13).

title: Jer 36:28
text: 36:28 Take another scroll. God’s word cannot be invalidated by the destruction of a scroll.

title: Jer 36:30
text: 36:30 Jehoiakim . . . shall have none to sit on the throne of David. His son Jehoiachin’s rule lasted only a few months (22:30 note; 2 Kin. 24:8).

title: Jer 37–39
text: 37:1–39:18 These chapters recount Jeremiah’s last warnings before the fall of Jerusalem and his imprisonment for his unpopular message. His repeated advice to surrender to the Babylonians is ignored, and he remains imprisoned until the fall of Jerusalem.

title: Jer 37:1
text: 37:1 Zedekiah . . . reigned instead of Coniah. See 2 Kin. 24:17–18. The year was 597 b.c.

title: Jer 37:5
text: 37:5 Egypt . . . Chaldeans. See 34:10, 11. Egypt and Babylon were in contention for the region. Many in Judah were looking to Egypt for support (24:8); the Babylonians would have withdrawn to counter the Egyptian advance.

title: Jer 37:15
text: 37:15 they beat him. This is the second mention of such punishment (20:2).

title: Jer 37:21
text: 37:21 the court of the guard. The court was less severe than the “dungeon” (v. 16; see 32:2). Zedekiah here shows a measure of respect for God’s prophet.

title: Jer 38:6
text: 38:6 cistern. This was likely a deep pit with only a small opening in the top. Whether it was empty from water shortage or disuse is not clear. They may have hoped Jeremiah would die there.

title: Jer 38:7
text:
38:7 Ebed-melech. The name means “king’s servant” and he would have held a position of responsibility in Zedekiah’s household.

king was sitting in the Benjamin Gate. Probably he was hearing civil suits (2 Sam. 15:2–4).

title: Jer 38:12
text: 38:12 rags . . . ropes. Here is a touching glimpse of Ebed-melech’s kindness.

title: Jer 38:14
text: 38:14 third entrance. This entrance is not mentioned elsewhere, but perhaps was for the private use of the king. The whole encounter breathes secrecy.

title: Jer 38:22
text:
38:22 women . . . led out to the officials. The loss of a harem was a humiliating consequence for a king defeated in war.

Your trusted friends. Lit. “men of your peace.” These “friends” included the officials who had counseled war (vv. 1, 4), and the false prophets (8:11). The expression ironically confirms Jeremiah’s criticism of them.

title: Jer 39:1
text: 39:1 tenth month. January, 588 b.c. (52:4; 2 Kin. 25:1).

title: Jer 39:2
text: 39:2 ninth day . . . month. That is, July, 586 b.c. (52:5–7; 2 Kin. 25:2–4); the siege had lasted two and a half years.

title: Jer 39:3
text: 39:3 sat in the middle gate. This fulfills 1:15. The officials’ names are formed with those of Babylonian gods (Nebo, Nergal).

title: Jer 39:11–12
text: 39:11, 12 Nebuchadnezzar . . . gave command concerning Jeremiah. How much of the prophet’s message the king knew is not clear; he probably regarded him as a Babylonian sympathizer (though see 25:12).

title: Jer 40:5
text: 40:5 Gedaliah. See 26:24. Gedaliah is receptive to Jeremiah’s understanding of events.

title: Jer 40:10
text: 40:10 gather wine and summer fruits and oil. At the moment of judgment, we are given a glimpse of future blessing in the land. Contrast the drought conditions during parts of Jeremiah’s earlier preaching (14:1–6 and notes).

title: Jer 41:1
text: 41:1 As they ate bread together. This hospitality emphasizes the treachery of Ishmael the son of Nethaniah.

title: Jer 41:5
text:
41:5 from Shechem . . . Shiloh . . . Samaria. These cities were important religious centers in the former northern kingdom that fell in 722 b.c. The men are a remnant of Israel’s population who had made pilgrimages to Jerusalem for the great feasts (in accordance with Ex. 23:14–17). The time of year (the “seventh month,” see v. 1) was the Feast of Booths.

with their beards shaved . . . bodies gashed. These actions are signs of mourning for the fall of Jerusalem.

the temple of the Lord. Although the temple had been destroyed, the temple mount was still regarded as holy.

title: Jer 41:7
text: 41:7 the city. That is, Mizpah (v. 6).

title: Jer 41:10
text:
41:10 the king’s daughters. Members of Zedekiah’s court, not just the king’s own daughters.

Ammonites. Part of the former alliance against Babylon (27:3), the Ammonite action is itself under God’s judgment (27:8; 49:1–6).

title: Jer 41:11–44:30
text: 41:11–44:30 Jeremiah is taken to Egypt by Jewish survivors fleeing from possible Babylonian reprisals.

title: Jer 41:15
text: 41:15 escaped . . . with eight men. Two men were presumably lost in the skirmish (v. 2).

title: Jer 42:10
text: 42:10 If you will remain in this land. This promise of blessing for the remnant left behind during the Exile was a new theme in Jeremiah’s message (24:8; 40:6).

title: Jer 42:13–16
text: 42:13–16 The Lord’s word is still against seeking refuge in Egypt (Deut. 17:16). The issue, as ever, is false trust and the delusion of safety in human power and calculation (22:20, 22; 30:14).

title: Jer 43:7–8
text:
43:7, 8 Egypt. Jeremiah’s prophetic ministry continues even in Egypt.

Tahpanhes. See 2:16. Tahpanhes was located in the eastern Nile delta.

title: Jer 43:9
text: 43:9 Take in your hands large stones . . . hide them. A symbolic action whose interpretation follows. The action was designed to show that the word would surely come to pass.

title: Jer 43:10
text: 43:10 Nebuchadnezzar . . . my servant. See note 25:9.

title: Jer 43:13
text: 43:13 obelisks. Characteristic examples of Egyptian architecture.

title: Jer 44:4
text: 44:4 this abomination. Idolatrous worship of other gods.

title: Jer 44:7
text: 44:7 no remnant. Possibly this oracle threatens that the restoration promised in 5:10 and 23:3 may not be carried out.

title: Jer 44:9
text: 44:9 Have you forgotten the evil. And by implication the judgment that resulted. Similarly, 2 Kin. 17:18–20 uses the judgment of the northern kingdom as a warning to Judah before her fall.

title: Jer 44:19
text: 44:19 without our husbands’ approval. See Num. 30:6–15. The women evidently took the lead in worshiping the queen of heaven (7:18).

title: Jer 44:23
text: 44:23 law . . . statutes . . . testimonies. The requirements of the Mosaic covenant (Deut. 11:1, 32; 12:1).

title: Jer 44:29–30
text: 44:29, 30 Pharaoh Hophra (reigned 589–570 b.c.) was killed by his enemies during a military revolt; his death is used as a sign that all the Lord’s prophecies against the refugees in Egypt would come to pass.

title: Jer 45
text: 45:1–5 This chapter contains God’s promise to Baruch to spare his life, made many years earlier.

title: Jer 45:1
text: 45:1 fourth year of Jehoiakim. The year in which Baruch prepared the first scroll of Jeremiah’s words for public reading (36:1–3).

title: Jer 45:3
text:
45:3 my pain. Baruch had evidently suffered along with Jeremiah as a result of Jeremiah’s prophetic commission (cf. 11:18–23). See 36:19; 43:3.

rest. See Deut. 12:9; Ps. 95:11.

title: Jer 46–51
text: 46:1–51:64 This section of Jeremiah comprises a series of judgment oracles against the surrounding nations.

title: Jer 46:2
text:
46:2 Carchemish. Nebuchadnezzar defeated Pharaoh Neco at the battle of Carchemish on the upper Euphrates River in 605 b.c. and brought to a close Egypt’s political and military influence over Palestine and Syria.

fourth year of Jehoiakim. See 36:1; 45:1. The ascendancy of Babylon over Egypt was critical for Judah in her final years.

title: Jer 46:3–4
text: 46:3, 4 Prepare buckler . . . put on your armor. These orders to the Egyptian army mock her military pretensions.

title: Jer 46:6
text: 46:6 by the river Euphrates. That is, at Carchemish (v. 2 note).

title: Jer 46:9
text: 46:9 men of Cush . . . Put . . . Lud. Mercenaries from Africa and Greece testify to Egypt’s power.

title: Jer 46:11
text:
46:11 Gilead. See note 8:22.

virgin daughter of Egypt. Suggesting vulnerability and innocence, though it could be meant ironically. See its use in connection with Israel in 14:17; 18:13.

title: Jer 46:14
text: 46:14 Migdol . . . Memphis . . . Tahpanhes. See 2:16; 43:8; 44:1.

title: Jer 46:15
text: 46:15 Why are your mighty ones face down. The Septuagint (Greek) reading is preferred by many interpreters: “Why has Apis run away?” Apis was the sacred bull of ancient Egypt, worshiped as an incarnation of the god Ptah, especially at Noph (Memphis, v. 14).

title: Jer 46:18
text:
46:18 As I live. See Gen. 22:15.

the King. For God as King, see 8:19; 10:7, 10; 48:15; 51:57; Deut. 33:5. In the oracles against the nations, God’s true kingship is contrasted with the vain pretensions of earthly kings.

Tabor . . . Carmel. These mountains in northern Israel stood at the eastern and western boundaries of the strategic Plain of Megiddo.

title: Jer 46:20
text:
46:20 heifer. This may be an ironic allusion to Egyptian worship of the bull Apis (v. 15 note).

biting fly. That is, Nebuchadnezzar.

from the north. See 6:1.

title: Jer 46:25
text: 46:25 Amon of Thebes. Amon was the chief Egyptian god. Thebes is in the south, suggesting even deeper penetration by Babylon.

title: Jer 47:4
text:
47:4 Tyre and Sidon. These Phoenician cities afforded natural protection to the Philistines farther down the Mediterranean coast, though it is not known whether alliances ever existed between them.

Caphtor. The Philistines’ place of origin, usually identified as Crete.

title: Jer 48
text: 48:1–47 This chapter records the oracle against Moab; cf. Is. 15; 16; Ezek. 25:8–11; Amos 2:1–3. Moab was an enemy of Israel (Judg. 3:12–14; 2 Kin. 3:4–27). It was an ally of Judah against Babylon (27:3), but supplied troops for Nebuchadnezzar against Jehoiakim (2 Kin. 24:2). Its defeat by Nebuchadnezzar may have come in 582 b.c. following a rebellion.

title: Jer 48:1
text: 48:1 Nebo . . . Kiriathaim. Originally these towns were allocated to the tribe of Reuben (Num. 32:3, 37, 38; Josh. 13:15, 19).

title: Jer 48:2
text: 48:2 Heshbon. This village was also assigned to Reuben (Num. 32:37; Josh. 13:17).

title: Jer 48:7
text: 48:7 Chemosh. A god of Moab worshiped by Solomon (1 Kin. 11:7, 33; 2 Kin. 23:13). Images of defeated gods were often carried off into exile.

title: Jer 48:8
text: 48:8 The destroyer. Probably Nebuchadnezzar.

title: Jer 48:11–12
text: 48:11, 12 The wine left to age represents Moab’s complacency. Their ease and security will vanish as quickly as a bottle empties when overturned.

title: Jer 48:13
text: 48:13 Bethel. Possibly a reference to the name El Bethel used for the Lord in Jeroboam’s apostate worship at Bethel (1 Kin. 12:28–30). That cult had not prevented the Assyrians from plundering the land in 722 b.c. (2 Kin. 18:9–12).

title: Jer 48:19
text: 48:19 Aroer. Southeast of Dibon, this border fortress on the Arnon River (v. 20) is here pictured anxiously watching the flight of the refugees.

title: Jer 48:20
text: 48:20 Arnon. That is, in the region along the Arnon. It was the most important river in Moab.

title: Jer 48:28
text: 48:28 dwell in the rock. See Is. 2:10.

title: Jer 48:32
text: 48:32 Sibmah . . . Sea of Jazer. See Is. 16:8.

title: Jer 48:38
text: 48:38 housetops of Moab. It was customary to offer incense upon rooftops as an act of worship (2 Kin. 23:12).

title: Jer 48:40
text: 48:40 eagle. This would be Nebuchadnezzar (Ezek. 17:3).

title: Jer 48:45–46
text:
48:45, 46 Derived from Num. 21:28, 29, but Jeremiah redirects Balaam’s prophecy against the Amorites by applying it to Moab.

Sihon. He was an Amorite ruler in Moses’ time, with his capital at Heshbon (Num. 21:21–30).

title: Jer 49:1–6
text: 49:1–6 A prophecy against the Ammonites. See Ezek. 25:1–7; Amos 1:13–15. Ammon, an old enemy of Israel (Judg. 11:4–33; 1 Sam. 11:1–11; 2 Sam. 10; 1 Kin. 4:13–19), was located in Trans-Jordan just north of Moab. Like Moab, it was part of an alliance against Babylon (27:3), and like Moab it supplied troops to Nebuchadnezzar against Judah (2 Kin. 24:2). Its hostility to Gedaliah (40:13–41:3) suggests a rebellion against Babylon, probably leading to an attack that virtually ended its existence as an autonomous nation.

title: Jer 49:1
text: 49:1 Milcom. The chief god of the Ammonites (32:35 note; 1 Kin. 11:5).

title: Jer 49:2
text: 49:2 Rabbah. This city is identified with modern Amman in Jordan.

title: Jer 49:3
text:
49:3 Heshbon. As a border town, it may have belonged to Ammon at some time also (Judg. 11:26).

Ai. Not the city of Ai familiar from the events of Josh. 8. Its location is not known.

title: Jer 49:7–22
text: 49:7–22 A prophecy against Edom. See also 27:3; Is. 21:11, 12; Ezek. 25:12–14; Amos 1:11, 12; Obad. 1–16. Edom was an old enemy of Israel (2 Sam. 8:13, 14) and had caused special bitterness by assisting Babylon against Judah.

title: Jer 49:7
text: 49:7 Teman. A region of Edom representing the whole.

title: Jer 49:8
text: 49:8 Esau. The brother of Jacob, whose name was another designation for Edom (Gen. 25:29, 30). See also Obad. 10.

title: Jer 49:13
text: 49:13 Bozrah. The capital of Edom.

title: Jer 49:22
text: 49:22 eagle. Probably Nebuchadnezzar (as 48:40), though the Edomites were also conquered decisively by Arabs during the sixth century b.c.

title: Jer 49:23–27
text: 49:23–27 A prophecy against Syria, or Aram. Syria impinged chiefly on the northern kingdom of Israel in the Assyrian period (1 Kin. 20; Amos 1:3–5). The three states named here had fallen to Assyria in the eighth century b.c.

title: Jer 49:23
text: 49:23 Damascus . . . Hamath . . . Arpad. These are major Aramean city-states.

title: Jer 49:28–33
text: 49:28–33 A prophecy against Arabian kingdoms. Arab nomadic tribes posed a periodic threat to settled communities (Judg. 6:1–6). The present prophecy may have been occasioned by an Arab uprising against Nebuchadnezzar in 598 b.c.

title: Jer 49:28
text:
49:28 Kedar. An Arab tribe well-known in the Old Testament period (Gen. 25:13; Is. 21:16, 17; 42:11).

Hazor. Also in the Arabian desert, and not the well-known Hazor in northern Israel; this name may have designated a number of Arab settlements including Teman, Buz, and Dedan (25:23, 24).

people of the east. Another designation for Arab tribal peoples (Judg. 6:3; 7:12; Job 1:3).

title: Jer 49:31
text: 49:31 dwells securely . . . no gates or bars. These nomadic peoples typically lived in unwalled towns, not depending on fortified cities. See the description of Laish in Judg. 18:7. They were no match for a well-armed invader.

title: Jer 49:34–39
text: 49:34–39 A prophecy against Elam, an important power to the east of Babylon, subjugated by Assyria, but resurgent in the Babylonian period. The prophecy possibly relates to a Babylonian containment campaign against Elam in 595 b.c.

title: Jer 50–51
text: 50:1–51:64 The prophecy against Babylon (cf. Is. 13:1–14:23; 21:1–9) is the climax of the book. The previous prophecies have served Jeremiah’s purpose of showing that Babylon would prevail over “all the nations” (27:7) for a period. Babylon has appeared up to this point as the instrument of God’s wrath. Finally, however (as in 25:17–26), “the word of the Lord” is uttered against Babylon itself, to show that its own time of judgment must come (25:11, 12). The Hebrew text of Jeremiah has placed the prophecy (actually delivered in 593 b.c.; see 51:59 note) at this point in the book so that the judgment on Babylon may occupy the climactic position. The relative length of the prophecy also shows how important Babylon is in the theology of the book.

title: Jer 50:2
text: 50:2 Bel . . . Merodach. Merodach or “Marduk” was the creator and chief deity in Babylonian myth. He was also called Bel, an early form of the word “Baal” (“lord”). See also Is. 46:1.

title: Jer 50:3
text: 50:3 out of the north a nation. See 1:14; 6:1. The tables are now turned on Babylon. The nation in question is not specified, but see 51:27, 28.

title: Jer 50:5
text: 50:5 everlasting covenant. See 31:31–34; 32:40; 33:20, 21.

title: Jer 50:9
text: 50:9 I am stirring up . . . against Babylon . . . from the north country. Cyrus is mentioned in Is. 41:25; 45:1. Members of the alliance are named in 51:27, 28.

title: Jer 50:12
text:
50:12 your mother. The city of Babylon is personified.

last of the nations. She had seemed invincible (Is. 14:12–17).

title: Jer 50:19
text: 50:19 Carmel . . . Bashan . . . hills of Ephraim and in Gilead. These are the most fertile parts of Israel.

title: Jer 50:21
text: 50:21 Merathaim . . . Pekod. These words are puns on Babylonian place-names (Marratu, Puqudu). The Hebrew words mean “double rebellion” and “punishment.”

title: Jer 50:24
text: 50:24 taken . . . you did not know it. The Persian defeat of Babylon was unexpected.

title: Jer 50:27
text: 50:27 bulls. That is, Babylon’s army (46:15 note).

title: Jer 50:28
text:
50:28 They flee. Jewish escapees from Babylon returned to Jerusalem.

vengeance for his temple. The burning of the temple (52:13) was the definitive destruction of Jerusalem. The Lord ties His vengeance on Babylon specifically to that.

title: Jer 50:29
text: 50:29 the Holy One of Israel. This name for God is frequent in Isaiah.

title: Jer 50:34
text: 50:34 Redeemer. See note 31:11.

title: Jer 51:11
text: 51:11 Medes. Babylon was conquered by an alliance of Medes and Persians (Introduction: Characteristics and Themes). See also Is. 13:17; 21:2.

title: Jer 51:13
text: 51:13 by many waters. Babylon was renowned for its irrigation channels, fed by the Euphrates River.

title: Jer 51:14
text: 51:14 sworn by himself. See Gen. 22:16 and note.

title: Jer 51:20
text: 51:20 You are my hammer. Apparently addressed to Babylon; vv. 20–23 should be taken together with vv. 24–26. Babylon was God’s “hammer” (50:23) against the nations, but later Babylon’s own sin would cause it to be judged.

title: Jer 51:27
text: 51:27 Ararat, Minni, and Ashkenaz. Assyrian administrative districts in Armenia.

title: Jer 51:30
text: 51:30 her dwellings are on fire. Babylon’s sacking of Judah (cf. 21:10) is being revenged by her Median conquerors.

title: Jer 51:33
text: 51:33 daughter of Babylon. This figure both personifies Babylon and alludes to its women, made vulnerable by defeat. See 50:42; Lam. 1:6 and note.

title: Jer 51:36
text: 51:36 plead . . . vengeance. See 50:15. The metaphors of revenge and courtroom judgment are mixed here.

title: Jer 51:44
text:
51:44 what he has swallowed. He “swallowed” the nations taken into exile and their treasures. Judah’s treasures were restored by Cyrus’s decree (Ezra 1:5–11).

wall of Babylon. An enormously wide double wall, further protected by an intervening moat.

title: Jer 51:51
text: 51:51 The exiles express their grief over the occupation of the temple by Nebuchadnezzar in 586 b.c., perhaps feeling that this defilement can never be cleansed.

title: Jer 51:53
text: 51:53 Though Babylon should mount up to heaven. Probably this is a reference to its lofty ziggurats, symbols of its religious pride (Gen. 11:4).

title: Jer 51:58
text:
51:58 high gates. The Ishtar Gate was known for its great height.

labor . . . the nations. The labor of subject nations in building Babylon’s fortifications will be of no use when God brings His judgment.

title: Jer 51:59
text:
51:59 Seraiah the son of Neriah. An official in Zedekiah’s administration, he was responsible for this expedition’s billeting en route. He is the brother of Baruch, Jeremiah’s scribe (32:12).

went with Zedekiah . . . to Babylon, in the fourth year of his reign. That is, in 593 b.c. The expedition may have been in response to a summons to explain Zedekiah’s part in the uprising against Nebuchadnezzar (27:3 note).

title: Jer 51:60
text: 51:60 a book. It may have contained the prophecies in chs. 50 and 51. See 36:2.

title: Jer 51:63–64
text: 51:63, 64 This final symbolic act (13:1–11 note) reinforced the last word of Jeremiah, that Babylon would fall.

title: Jer 52
text: 52:1–34 The final chapter of Jeremiah is an appendix describing the fall of Jerusalem and reminding the reader that Jeremiah’s prophecies were fulfilled. Despite its message of divine judgment for sin, the Book of Jeremiah ends (like 2 Kings) on a hopeful note by calling attention to the mercy shown to King Jehoiachin of Judah while in Babylonian exile (52:31–34; cf. 2 Kin. 25:27–30).

title: Jer 52:1
text: 52:1 Jeremiah of Libnah. Not Jeremiah the prophet, who was from Anathoth (1:1).

title: Jer 52:12
text: 52:12 the tenth day. 2 Kin. 25:8 has the “seventh day.” One or the other text could be a copyist’s error.

title: Jer 52:22
text: 52:22 five. 2 Kin. 25:17 has “three.” See note on v. 12.

title: Jer 52:25
text: 52:25 seven. 2 Kin. 25:19 has “five.” See note on v. 12.

title: Jer 52:28–30
text: 52:28–30 These verses refer to the two main deportations of Jews to Babylon, in 597 b.c. (“the seventh year”) and 586 b.c. (the “eighteenth year”; “nineteenth” in v. 12 is due to an alternate way of counting). A third, smaller deportation is also mentioned. The numbers here are smaller than those in 2 Kin. 24:14, 16, and may count only adult males.

title: Jer 52:31
text: 52:31 twenty-fifth. 2 Kin. 25:27 has “twenty-seventh.” See note on v. 12.
